_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A. Accidental Release Prevention Policy and Emergency Response Policy



1. The top priority of US Foods Inc. is to provide a healthy and safe work environment for its employees and the surrounding community.  In this effort, US Foods Inc. has developed strict policies and procedures to reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous chemical release.  The Process Safety Management (PSM) program acts as a gatekeeper of these policies and procedures.



2. The requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) PSM Standard CFR 1910.119 mirrors that of Risk Management's Prevention Program 3 and therefore has been integrated.  Of the 14 PSM elements, 13 focus on accidental release prevention and 1 on emergency planning and response.  It is the commitment of management and employees to follow the established procedures and seek new ways for improvement.



3. In the event of an emergency US Foods Inc. will evacuate or shelter in place, depending on the type and magnitude of the emergency, is employees and call the North Little Rock Fire Department to respond to the emergency.



B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



1. US Foods Inc. is a foodservice distributor located in North Little Rock, Arkansas.  The process includes refrigerated spaces that utilize anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.  Anhydrous ammonia is a regulated substance under the Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions, 40 CFR 68.



C. General Accidental Release Prevention Program Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



1. EPA's Risk Management Prevention Program 3, 40 CFR Part 68 (D) and OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard 29 CFR 1910.119 outline the facilities accidental release prevention program.  Included are 13 Chemical Specific Prevention steps implemented by US Foods Inc. and are summarized below:

-Employee Participation - Employees are given shared responsibility with management in the continued evolution of the program.

-Process Safety Information - Chemica

l, equipment, and system information has been compiled to ensure the safe design and operation.

-Process Hazard Analysis - What-if Checklist completed to identify potential hazards and minimize their impact.

-Operating Procedures - Standard Operating Procedures developed to ensure the safe operation of the process.

-Training - Training program established, and operators trained to ensure the safe operation of the process.

-Contractors - Contractor program established to ensure only qualified and trained contractor work on or near the process.

-Pre-Startup Safety Review - Procedures and checklist developed to ensure all safety requirements completed before startup of new or modified process.

-Mechanical Integrity - Program developed to ensure equipment and systems installed per design specifications and maintained per manufacturer recommendations and good engineering practices. 

-Hot Work Permit - Permit program established to prevent the potential of fire/explosion resulting from hot work near hazardous chemicals.

-Management of Change - Procedures established to manage process changes to ensure the integrity of the PSM program is maintained.

-Incident Investigation - Procedures established to investigate releases that resulted in or could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a hazardous chemical to prevent reoccurrence.

-Compliance Audits - Procedures established to periodically review program implementation and to correct as necessary.

-Trade Secrets - Policy implemented to provide all necessary information regardless of trade secrets to ensure the employee safety.



D. Accident History - Last Five Years

There is no accident history in the past five years.



E. Emergency Response Program



1. US Foods Inc. is included in the written community emergency response plan.  The facility has its own emergency action plan.  The emergency action plan includes procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release.  The em

ergency action plan also included information on emergency health care.



2. US Foods Inc. does not respond to emergencies.  US Foods Inc. coordinates its Emergency Action Plan with the North Little Rock Fire Department.



F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



1. US Foods, Inc. facility is proactive on performing audits and hazard analysis per their Process Safety Management and Risk Management programs.  Any areas for improvement during these audits and hazard analysis are identified and corrective actions are recommended.  All recommendations are promptly addressed.
